item.title: Adingani i Lahi-hu
item.description: Talking To My Son A note: this is a modified post from when I was blogging on write.as. Most of the Chamoru that I’ve been using lately is towards i lahi-hu. H√•cha na s√•kkan id√•t-√±a, pues inadingan-m√•mi ni ti mapput. I wanted to share some of those phrases with you and perhaps get some feedback. If you’re here then I’ll assume you came from Twitter, IG, or some other social media site.

item.title: I Tinituhon
item.description: Buenas yan h√•fa adai todus hamyu! Guahu i che’lun-miyu as David Taitingfong ya ini iyo-ku na blog ni’ un tataitai. I’ve been meaning to get this space started for some time but, if I’m being honest, so many things have gotten in my way - and by many things I mean myself and the plethora of projects that I can’t seem to stop accruing. But as they say: there’s no better time than the present…so here we are!

item.title: Sources
item.description: Lista na Tiningu’ A list of Chamoru resources that I frequent: Resource Notes Learning Chamoru Chamoru dictionary & lessons. Account required. Chamorro Grammar by Sandra Chung. Downloadable PDF. Minag√•het Blog by Michael Lujan Bevacqua. General Chamoru knowledge. Lengguahi-ta by Schyuler; blog to document her Chamoru language learning journey Trini Learns Chamorro by Trini; their blog to actively practice Chamoru

item.title: About Me
